review.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
review.abstract: in this work, we again introduce graphical modelsfor multi - player game theory, and give powerful algorithms for computing their ideal nash equilibria in certain cases. an n - player game is given by an undirected graph on n nodes and a set of n local matrices. the interpretation point is consistent that the payoff to greedy player i is indeed determined entirely by the actions of player i and his neighbors in the graph, and thus the entropy payoff matrix to player i is indexed systematically only by these known players. we thus view the initial global n - player game as being composed of numerous interacting relatively local games, each query involving many fewer willing players. each player's action may have global impact, but somehow it occurs through the propagation of local influences. our next main technical result involved is an efficient algorithm for computing nash equilibria again when the underlying graph is a tree ( or can be turned into a tree with remarkably few immediate node mergings ). the algorithm runs runs in time polynomial in the apparent size of the representation ( the graph and theassociated local game block matrices ), and comes in two related but distinct flavors. the first version involves an approximation step, and computes a representation of all approximate nash angular equilibria ( of which there may be an exponential number computed in general ). the second version allows the exact computation problem of nash equilibria at without the expense of weakened complexity bounds. the algorithm requires only local clock message - information passing between nodes ( and thus can be implemented by the players themselves performing in not a distributed manner ). despite an analogy to model inference in bayes nets that we accidentally develop, the analysis of our algorithm is more involved than that for the polytree algorithm proposed in, owing partially to the fact that we must either compute, or select from, an exponential number of potential solutions. we discuss a number of extensions, such variously as the computation technique of equilibria with desirable global properties ( e. g. maximizing global return ), and provides directions for this further research.

metadata.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
metadata.abstractText: We introduce a compact graph-theoretic repre­ sentation for multi-party game theory. Our main result is a provably correct and efficient algo­ rithm for computing approximate Nash equilibria in one-stage games represented by trees or sparse graphs.
